docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina will take its dispute over plans by British oil companies to explore for oil off the coast of the Falkland Islands to the United Nations next week.

docs.lead_paragraph: The retired admirals attacked the decision to scrap Britain’s only aircraft carrier and its fleet of Harrier jump jets, saying it exposed the Falkland Islands to attack by Argentina.

headline.seo: British Commanders Say Defense Cuts Risk Falklands

docs.lead_paragraph: Graciela, Ofelia and Pedro from Patagonia stood around the counter with me in Buenos Aires, chomping on pizza slices and trying to explain  why Argentines dine so late. It was 8 p.m. and they were snacking on their way home from work to tide them over before dinner. We were at Guerrin, an institution where you get to know the strangers standing next to you because you're in close quarters and there's nothing to do but talk. (My primary rule for lone travelers: always talk to strangers. At the very least you could end up with a bit of conversation over pizza. At best, you end up getting set up on a blind date. But more on that later.)
docs.abstract: Buenos Aires, once a bargain, is now simply a reasonably priced city with a well-deserved reputation as the Paris of South America - easy to walk, full of broad boulevards, plenty of made-in-France-and- assembled-in-Argentina architecture, old-fashioned corner cafes with comfortable wooden seats to while away the day.
